ordered.reason: Both the START and TARGET papers deal with agents and memory/reasoning. This paper's title directly mentions 'MemoryBank' which is very similar to the START paper's title and likely shares conceptual themes relevant to the TARGET.

ordered.title: MemOS: An Operating System for Memory-Augmented Generation (MAG) in Large Language Models
ordered.reason: This paper focuses on memory augmentation in LLMs, a key component of the START paper and conceptually related to the TARGET paper's focus on style transfer which could be enhanced by memory.

ordered.title: M+: Extending MemoryLLM with Scalable Long-Term Memory
ordered.reason: Similar to MemOS, this paper discusses extending LLM memory, which is a core concept in the START paper and could be relevant to improving agent capabilities in tasks like style transfer (TARGET).

ordered.title: A Survey on the Memory Mechanism of Large Language Model-based Agents
ordered.reason: As a survey on memory mechanisms for LLM agents, this paper would likely cover foundational concepts and related work that might include style transfer or methods that could be applied to it.

ordered.title: Evaluating Very Long-Term Conversational Memory of LLM Agents
ordered.reason: Focuses on long-term memory in LLM agents, a key aspect of the START paper. Improved memory could indirectly benefit tasks like style transfer by allowing agents to retain context and stylistic preferences.

ordered.title: In Prospect and Retrospect: Reflective Memory Management for Long-term Personalized Dialogue Agents
ordered.reason: This paper's focus on 'memory management' and 'long-term personalization' aligns with the general theme of agent memory present in the START paper and potentially applicable to nuanced tasks like style transfer.

ordered.title: PRIME: Large Language Model Personalization with Cognitive Dual-Memory and Personalized Thought Process
ordered.reason: The concepts of 'cognitive dual-memory' and 'personalized thought process' are relevant to agent capabilities and could be applied to style transfer for more personalized results.

ordered.reason: This paper directly addresses agent procedural memory, which is a core component of the START paper. This type of memory could be relevant for agents performing complex tasks like style transfer.

ordered.reason: Focuses on scalable long-term memory for AI agents, a theme shared with the START paper. Such memory systems could be leveraged for style transfer tasks.

ordered.reason: Memory augmentation for planning and task automation is relevant to the agent-centric nature of the START paper. This could be extended to tasks requiring planning for stylistic changes.

ordered.reason: Deals with hierarchical working memory management for agents, a concept closely related to the START paper's focus on reasoning and memory. This is broadly applicable to complex tasks.

ordered.title: Self-evolving Agents with reflective and memory-augmented abilities
ordered.reason: This paper directly mentions 'self-evolving agents' and 'memory-augmented abilities', which are central to the START paper and could apply to agents that learn and adapt style transfer techniques.

ordered.reason: Explicitly links memory and reasoning for agents, aligning with the START paper's themes. This synergy is beneficial for complex tasks like style transfer.

ordered.reason: Focuses on 'agentic memory' for LLM agents, directly connecting to the START paper's domain. Such memory can enhance an agent's ability to perform tasks like style transfer.

ordered.reason: This paper presents a 'Memory Agent' for LLMs, which directly relates to the START paper. Such agents could be trained or adapted for style transfer tasks.

ordered.reason: The evaluation of memory in LLM agents is a fundamental aspect of research in this area, making it relevant to any agent performing complex tasks, including style transfer.

ordered.reason: This survey covers 'self-evolving agents,' a core concept in the START paper. It provides a broad overview that might touch upon applications like style transfer or the underlying mechanisms.

ordered.reason: A general survey on autonomous agents, which could include discussions on memory, reasoning, and diverse applications, potentially encompassing style transfer.

ordered.reason: Focuses on 'agent self-evolution,' a direct link to the START paper. The strategy described could be applied to learning new skills like style transfer.

ordered.reason: This paper is about self-improvement of language agents using experience replay. This learning paradigm could be applied to improving style transfer capabilities.

ordered.reason: Focuses on learning from errors, which is a form of self-improvement and relevant to agent development. This could be applied to refining style transfer.

ordered.reason: This paper focuses on 'self-evolving agents' that learn from experience. This adaptive learning is relevant to agents that might need to master style transfer.

ordered.reason: This paper is about agents for software engineering. The agent concept is shared, and 'automated' tasks might involve stylistic elements.

ordered.title: Mem0: Building Production-Ready AI Agents with Scalable Long-Term Memory
ordered.reason: Focuses on scalable long-term memory for AI agents, a theme shared with the START paper. Such memory systems could be leveraged for style transfer tasks.

ordered.title: A Simple Framework for Contrastive Learning of Visual Representations
ordered.reason: This paper is about contrastive learning for visual representations. It's a general machine learning technique with no direct relation to agents, self-evolution, or style transfer.

ranked.title: ReAct: Synergizing Reasoning and Acting in Language Models
ranked.reason: The TARGET paper focuses on style transfer, a task that often involves reasoning about linguistic structures and transforming them. ReAct directly addresses the synergy between reasoning and acting, which is highly relevant for complex tasks like style transfer where understanding and manipulation are key.

ranked.title: ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning
ranked.reason: Style transfer can be viewed as an exploratory task where the model needs to 'try out' different linguistic transformations to achieve the desired style. ExACT's focus on exploration and learning from mistakes, combined with reflective learning, aligns well with the iterative nature of refining stylistic elements.

ranked.title: Self-Refine: Iterative Refinement with Self-Feedback
ranked.reason: Style transfer is an iterative process. Self-Refine's approach to improving outputs through self-feedback is directly applicable to refining the stylistic aspects of text, making it a strong candidate.

ranked.title: Inducing Programmatic Skills for Agentic Tasks
ranked.reason: Style transfer can be framed as inducing specific 'programmatic skills' or transformation rules. This paper's focus on learning such skills for agents is relevant to developing precise control over linguistic output for stylistic changes.

ranked.title: Learning Wisdom from Errors: Promoting LLM's Continual Relation Learning through Exploiting Error Cases
ranked.reason: Achieving a specific style often involves navigating linguistic nuances and avoiding 'errors' in style. Learning from mistakes, as proposed in this paper, is crucial for fine-tuning style transfer to produce natural and accurate results.

ranked.title: In-Context Principle Learning from Mistakes
ranked.reason: Similar to 'Learning Wisdom from Errors', this paper's focus on learning principles from mistakes is highly relevant for style transfer, where misapplying a stylistic transformation can lead to undesirable outcomes. Learning these underlying principles is key to successful transfer.

ranked.title: ReasonIR: Training Retrievers for Reasoning Tasks
ranked.reason: Style transfer often requires reasoning about the source text and the target style. This paper's focus on training retrievers for reasoning tasks suggests mechanisms that could be used to identify and apply relevant stylistic knowledge.

ranked.title: RAP: Retrieval-Augmented Planning with Contextual Memory for Multimodal LLM Agents
ranked.reason: The target task, style transfer, can benefit from retrieval-augmented approaches to find relevant stylistic patterns or examples. The planning aspect is also relevant for orchestrating the transformation process.

ranked.title: Synapse: Trajectory-as-Exemplar Prompting with Memory for Computer Control
ranked.reason: Style transfer can be seen as a form of 'computer control' over text. Using trajectories as exemplars with memory aligns with the idea of learning specific transformation paths for style transfer.

ranked.title: ExpeL: LLM Agents Are Experiential Learners
ranked.reason: Style transfer benefits from learning from examples and experiences. ExpeL's focus on experiential learning for LLM agents could provide a framework for agents to learn and adapt to different style transfer requirements.

ranked.title: Autonomous Evaluation and Refinement of Digital Agents
ranked.reason: Improving style transfer can be framed as refining the agent's ability to perform this task. Autonomous evaluation and refinement processes are directly applicable to enhancing the quality of style transfer outputs.

ranked.title: Self-evolving Agents with reflective and memory-augmented abilities
ranked.reason: This paper's focus on self-evolving agents with reflection and memory suggests a robust framework for agents that need to adapt and improve their performance, which is applicable to learning and executing complex stylistic transformations.

ranked.title: MEM1: Learning to Synergize Memory and Reasoning for Efficient Long-Horizon Agents
ranked.reason: Style transfer can be a long-horizon task, especially when dealing with complex texts or subtle stylistic changes. Synergizing memory and reasoning, as this paper suggests, is crucial for efficiently handling such tasks.

ranked.title: Contextual Experience Replay for Self-Improvement of Language Agents
ranked.reason: Improving style transfer involves learning from past attempts. Contextual experience replay can help agents learn from specific stylistic examples and improve their performance over time.

ranked.title: In Prospect and Retrospect: Reflective Memory Management for Long-term Personalized Dialogue Agents
ranked.reason: While focused on dialogue, the concepts of prospective and retrospective reflection, along with memory management, are relevant to understanding and implementing nuanced stylistic changes.

ranked.title: Thinking vs. Doing: Agents that Reason by Scaling Test-Time Interaction
ranked.reason: Style transfer requires both understanding (thinking) and executing the transformation (doing). This paper's approach to agents that reason through test-time interaction could inform how to best execute stylistic changes.

ranked.title: A Survey on the Memory Mechanism of Large Language Model-based Agents
ranked.reason: Effective style transfer often requires remembering stylistic features or constraints. A survey on memory mechanisms in LLM agents is relevant to understanding how to equip agents with the necessary memory for this task.

ranked.title: A Survey on Large Language Model based Autonomous Agents
ranked.reason: Understanding autonomous agents is foundational. This survey could provide context on agent capabilities that are relevant to performing complex text transformations like style transfer.

ranked.title: Mind2Web: Towards a Generalist Agent for the Web
ranked.reason: Web agents perform complex tasks on web pages. Style transfer, while not web-specific, shares the characteristic of understanding and manipulating structured information (text).

ranked.title: A Real-World WebAgent with Planning, Long Context Understanding, and Program Synthesis
ranked.reason: Similar to Mind2Web, this paper's focus on planning, understanding, and program synthesis in web agents is relevant to the procedural aspects of style transfer.

ranked.title: WebArena: A Realistic Web Environment for Building Autonomous Agents
ranked.reason: While focused on web tasks, the underlying principles of agent design and evaluation in realistic environments could be applied to style transfer tasks.

ranked.title: WebChoreArena: Evaluating Web Browsing Agents on Realistic Tedious Web Tasks
ranked.reason: Evaluating agents on tedious tasks is relevant to the potential complexity and fine-grained nature of style transfer.

ranked.title: OSWorld: Benchmarking Multimodal Agents for Open-Ended Tasks in Real Computer Environments
ranked.reason: This paper benchmarks agents on open-ended tasks. Style transfer can be considered an open-ended task where the goal is to achieve a certain aesthetic or stylistic outcome.

ranked.title: SWE-agent: Agent-Computer Interfaces Enable Automated Software Engineering
ranked.reason: Automated software engineering involves complex transformations and understanding of code structure. This could be analogous to understanding and transforming linguistic structures for style.

ranked.title: Gemini Embedding: Generalizable Embeddings from Gemini
ranked.reason: Good embeddings are crucial for understanding text. Generalizable embeddings might capture stylistic nuances better, aiding style transfer.

ranked.title: S*: Test Time Scaling for Code Generation
ranked.reason: Test-time scaling is a technique that can be applied to various generation tasks. Its application to code generation might offer insights into scaling for text generation with stylistic constraints.

ranked.title: s1: Simple test-time scaling
ranked.reason: Similar to S*, this paper focuses on test-time scaling, a potentially relevant optimization for applying style transfer models.

ranked.title: Z1: Efficient Test-time Scaling with Code
ranked.reason: Another paper on test-time scaling, highlighting its importance in efficient generation, which could apply to style transfer.

ranked.title: Scaling Test-time Compute for LLM Agents
ranked.reason: This paper directly addresses scaling test-time compute for LLM agents, which could be beneficial for complex style transfer tasks.

ranked.title: Scaling Test-Time Compute Without Verification or RL is Suboptimal
ranked.reason: This paper offers a nuanced view on test-time scaling, suggesting that incorporating verification or RL can improve outcomes, which might be relevant for ensuring stylistic accuracy.

ranked.title: Two Heads are Better Than One: Test-time Scaling of Multi-agent Collaborative Reasoning
ranked.reason: Multi-agent collaborative reasoning could be adapted for style transfer, where different agents might focus on different stylistic aspects or levels of transformation.

ranked.title: Gemini 2.5: Pushing the Frontier with Advanced Reasoning, Multimodality, Long Context, and Next Generation Agentic Capabilities
